description: Controls for detecting, responding to, containing, and recovering from information security incidents. Covers the complete incident lifecycle from preparation through lessons learned, including communication protocols and forensic readiness.

controls.title: Incident Response Plan
controls.description: Verify that a formal, documented Incident Response Plan (IRP) exists and is approved by senior management. The plan should define incident categories and severity levels, roles and responsibilities (including an Incident Response Team), escalation procedures, communication protocols (internal and external), and integration with business continuity and disaster recovery plans.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain the current Incident Response Plan. 2. Verify the plan was approved by senior management and reviewed within the past 12 months. 3. Confirm the plan defines incident severity levels with classification criteria. 4. Verify the plan includes contact lists, escalation paths, and communication templates. 5. Confirm the plan addresses regulatory notification requirements (e.g., GDPR 72-hour, state breach notification).
controls.expected_evidence: Incident Response Plan document with approval signatures, review history, IRT roster with contact information, escalation matrix, communication templates, regulatory notification procedures

framework_mapping.ISO 27001: A.5.24 Information Security Incident Management Planning
framework_mapping.COBIT: DSS02.01 Define Incident and Service Request Classification Schemes

controls.title: Incident Detection and Monitoring Capabilities
controls.description: Verify that the organization has deployed adequate detection capabilities to identify security incidents in a timely manner. This includes SIEM, IDS/IPS, EDR, and other monitoring tools configured with alert rules for common attack patterns, anomalous behavior, and policy violations.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Inventory all security monitoring tools deployed (SIEM, IDS/IPS, EDR, DLP). 2. Review SIEM use case library and alert rules for coverage of common threats. 3. Verify that critical log sources are integrated into the SIEM (firewalls, servers, applications, authentication). 4. Test detection capability by reviewing response to recent alert triggers. 5. Confirm 24/7 monitoring coverage (SOC, managed service, or on-call rotation).
controls.expected_evidence: Security monitoring tool inventory, SIEM use case catalog, log source integration list, sample alert triggers and response, SOC or managed security service agreement, monitoring schedule

framework_mapping.COBIT: DSS02.02 Record, Classify, and Prioritize Requests and Incidents

controls.title: Incident Classification and Triage
controls.description: Verify that a defined classification scheme exists for categorizing incidents by type (malware, unauthorized access, data breach, denial of service, insider threat) and severity (critical, high, medium, low). The classification should drive response priority, resource allocation, and escalation requirements.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review the incident classification matrix/taxonomy. 2. Verify classification criteria are clear and actionable. 3. Select 10 recent incidents and verify they were correctly classified. 4. Confirm that severity-driven SLAs exist (e.g., critical incidents triaged within 15 minutes). 5. Verify that classification drives appropriate escalation (e.g., critical incidents escalate to CISO).
controls.expected_evidence: Incident classification matrix, severity definitions with SLAs, sample incident tickets showing classification, escalation records for high-severity incidents

framework_mapping.NIST CSF: DE.AE-4 Impact of events is determined

controls.title: Incident Containment Procedures
controls.description: Verify that documented containment procedures exist for each major incident category. Containment strategies should minimize damage and prevent further compromise while preserving forensic evidence. Both short-term containment (immediate isolation) and long-term containment (temporary fixes while preparing eradication) should be addressed.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review containment procedures for major incident types (malware, unauthorized access, data exfiltration). 2. Verify procedures address evidence preservation during containment. 3. Review recent incidents to confirm containment actions were taken per procedure. 4. Verify that containment actions are authorized by appropriate personnel. 5. Confirm that containment does not unnecessarily destroy forensic evidence.
controls.expected_evidence: Containment procedure documents by incident type, containment action logs from recent incidents, evidence preservation checklists, containment authorization records

framework_mapping.ISO 27001: A.5.26 Response to Information Security Incidents
framework_mapping.COBIT: DSS02.04 Investigate, Diagnose, and Allocate Incidents

controls.title: Incident Response Team and Roles
controls.description: Verify that an Incident Response Team (IRT) is formally designated with defined roles, responsibilities, and authority. The IRT should include representatives from IT security, IT operations, legal, communications/PR, HR, and business leadership. Team members should be trained and available to respond within defined timeframes.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain the IRT roster with roles and contact information. 2. Verify IRT membership is current and covers required functional areas. 3. Confirm that IRT members are aware of their roles and have been trained. 4. Review on-call schedules to verify adequate coverage. 5. Verify that the IRT has authority to take containment actions (e.g., isolate systems, disable accounts) without lengthy approval chains.
controls.expected_evidence: IRT roster and charter, role descriptions, training records for IRT members, on-call schedule, authority delegation documentation

framework_mapping.ISO 27001: A.5.24 Information Security Incident Management Planning

controls.title: Incident Response Testing and Exercises
controls.description: Verify that the incident response plan is tested at least annually through tabletop exercises, functional drills, or full-scale simulations. Exercises should test different scenarios, involve key personnel, and result in documented lessons learned that are incorporated into plan updates.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain records of incident response exercises conducted in the past 12 months. 2. Verify exercises test realistic scenarios relevant to the organization's threat landscape. 3. Confirm key IRT members and management participated. 4. Review exercise after-action reports for identified improvement opportunities. 5. Verify that exercise findings were incorporated into plan updates.
controls.expected_evidence: Exercise planning documents, participant attendance lists, exercise scenario descriptions, after-action reports, plan update records based on exercise findings

framework_mapping.ISO 27001: A.5.24 Information Security Incident Management Planning
framework_mapping.COBIT: DSS02.07 Track Status and Produce Reports

controls.title: Forensic Investigation Readiness
controls.description: Verify that the organization has forensic investigation capabilities or retainer agreements with external forensic firms. Systems should be configured to preserve forensic artifacts, and procedures should exist for evidence collection, chain of custody, and preservation in a legally defensible manner.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review the forensic investigation procedure. 2. Verify forensic tools are available (disk imaging, memory capture, network capture). 3. Confirm external forensic firm retainer agreement if internal capability is limited. 4. Review evidence handling procedures for chain of custody requirements. 5. Verify that system configurations support forensic artifact preservation (logging, retention, NTP sync).
controls.expected_evidence: Forensic investigation procedure, forensic tool inventory, external retainer agreement, chain of custody forms, system logging and time synchronization configuration

framework_mapping.COBIT: DSS02.04 Investigate, Diagnose, and Allocate Incidents

controls.title: Incident Communication and Notification
controls.description: Verify that communication procedures define who must be notified during and after incidents, including internal stakeholders (executive management, board, legal), external parties (regulators, law enforcement, affected individuals, customers), and third parties (insurance, vendors). Communication templates should be pre-prepared for common scenarios.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review the incident communication plan and notification matrix. 2. Verify communication templates exist for different incident types and audiences. 3. Confirm regulatory notification requirements are documented with timelines (e.g., 72-hour GDPR, state breach laws). 4. Review recent incidents to verify communication procedures were followed. 5. Confirm legal counsel is involved in communication decisions for data breaches.
controls.expected_evidence: Communication plan and notification matrix, pre-prepared communication templates, regulatory notification procedure with timelines, recent incident communication records, legal review evidence

framework_mapping.ISO 27001: A.5.26 Response to Information Security Incidents
framework_mapping.COBIT: DSS02.06 Close Service Requests and Incidents

controls.title: Incident Eradication and Recovery
controls.description: Verify that procedures exist for eradicating the root cause of incidents (removing malware, closing vulnerabilities, resetting compromised credentials) and restoring affected systems to normal operations. Recovery should include validation that the threat has been eliminated and systems are functioning correctly before returning to production.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review eradication and recovery procedures for common incident types. 2. For recent incidents, verify that root cause was identified and eradicated. 3. Confirm that recovery steps included validation/testing before returning systems to production. 4. Verify that compromised credentials were reset and affected systems were reimaged or patched. 5. Confirm that monitoring was enhanced post-recovery to detect recurrence.
controls.expected_evidence: Eradication and recovery procedures, root cause analysis documentation from recent incidents, system restoration and validation records, credential reset evidence, post-recovery enhanced monitoring evidence

framework_mapping.ISO 27001: A.5.26 Response to Information Security Incidents
framework_mapping.COBIT: DSS02.05 Resolve and Recover from Incidents
framework_mapping.PCI-DSS: 12.10.6 Modify and evolve incident response plan

controls.title: Post-Incident Review and Lessons Learned
controls.description: Verify that a formal post-incident review (lessons learned) is conducted after every significant incident. The review should identify what went well, what could be improved, root cause analysis, and actionable improvement recommendations. Findings should be tracked to completion and incorporated into policy/procedure updates.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review the post-incident review procedure and required triggers. 2. For significant incidents in the past 12 months, verify post-incident reviews were conducted. 3. Evaluate the quality of reviews (root cause identified, specific recommendations made). 4. Verify that recommendations were assigned owners and tracked to completion. 5. Confirm that incident response plan updates were made based on lessons learned.
controls.expected_evidence: Post-incident review reports, root cause analysis documentation, recommendation tracking log with status, incident response plan revision history showing updates from lessons learned
